bibl.title: Letter from Cornelia Knox Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, May 4, 1951

div1.p: Kean writes Hench about her interactions with Standlee who is writing a biography of Reed. She encloses a copy of the letter she sent to Standlee, critiquing Standlee's manuscript. She mentions that Love is not happy with the way Standlee is writing of Reed.

div1.head: Letter from Cornelia Knox Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, May 4, 1951
div1.opener:
2804 N STREET, N. W.
GEORGETOWN
WASHINGTON 7, D. C.
4 May 1951
Dear Colonel Hench:
div1.p:
When your letter came my first re-
action was that of sorrow and regret
that you should be burdened with such
a distressing problem. You have met
it in your masterly way.

The next morning after your letter
came Mrs. Standlee Telephoned to ask
if she could come to see me. I told
her I had given General Kean's Diaries,
two weeks ago to his son in Richmond.
She came and I told her I hoped she
would do, as I felt-deeply, that she
would take Dr. Hench's work on Walter
Reed and Yellow Fever as gospel. She
left her manuscript with me, asking me to
criticize it, and saying she would not
be offended at what I might say.
I enclose a copy of my letter to her.

Have I your permission to show
your letter to me to others? I have
told General Albert G. Love he could
read it when he comes to see me. Do
you know him? He is a wonderful man,
kind and good and able. I call
him “my Rod and my Staff”. When General Kean
died he came to me at once and attended
to everything for me. He and General Kean
were devoted friends. And I know he
does not approve of the way Mrs. Standlee
has written of Walter Reed.

With love to you and your dear mary,
and my gratitude
